title: Revered tortoise with 'healing powers' dies 'aged 344' at Nigerian emperor's palace
text:
A tortoise that was believed to be 344 years old with healing powers has died in the Nigerian palace where it lived.

Alagba, meaning 'Elder', the tortoise died today after suffering from a brief illness.

She lived in Nigeria with the ruler of Ogbomoso’s palace, Oba Jimoh Oyewumi Ajagungbade III, until her death.

Alagba, meaning 'Elder', the tortoise died today aged 344 after suffering from a brief illness

And she is believed to be the oldest tortoise in Africa, if not the world.

Ogbomoso's town crier, Samuel Ojo, said Alagba was brought into the palace by the third traditional ruler of the city, Isan Okumoyede, over three centuries ago.

She also had two staff members of the palace dedicated to her and it is believed that she played host to many monarchs throughout her lifetime.

She lived in Nigeria with the ruler of Ogbomoso’s palace, Oba Jimoh Oyewumi Ajagungbade III (pictured), until her deat

Alagba's body will be embalmed so it can be preserved for historical records and so adoring tourists will be able to carry on visiting her.

Could Alagba really be 344 years old? While most domestic tortoises usually only live between 10-80 years, others are thought to be able to live far longer. The oldest tortoise on record was called Adwaita, who lived at the Alipore Zooilogical Gardens in Kolkata, India. Staff believed Adwaita was around 250 years old when he died in 2006. Although Alagba's age does seem staggering, some tortoise conservationists believe that some of the creatures can live for 500 years.

Private Secretary to Oba Oyewumi, Toyin Ajamu, told the Daily Post that the staff members who looked after Alagba 'provided food, health support and other logistics, so as to make sure she gets the best treatment'.

He added: 'On a daily basis, Alagba had tourists visiting her from different parts of the world.

'The palace household, Ogbomoso community and stakeholders in the tourism sector are mourning Alagba’s passage.'

Other than Alagba, the oldest known tortoise was Adwaita - an aldabra giant tortoise that died in 2006 and is believed to have been 250 years old.

Adwaita, lived at the Alipore Zoological Gardens in Kolkata, India, was supposedly born around 1750 and was one of four tortoises that was brought back to India by British sailors from the Seychelles as a gift for Lord Clive.
